history.content:
I wouldn't necessarily say that CS 188 is unnecessary - I haven't taken it, but from what I've heard it's really useful to take before 189, especially since you're interested in studying AI.  I'd also recommend that you take EECS 126 and 127 before 189 rather than concurrently.  I'd also recommend you take CS 169 (software engineering) at some point, because the skills you learn from it, such as building large programming projects and programming in a group with other people, are applicable to other classes as well as real-world industry positions.  

-----

Just personally, Fall 2020 looks a little tight to me; those (16B/170/61C at the time) are all pretty time consuming and/or conceptually difficult classes from what I've heard and you also might like to set aside some time to brush up data structures for coding interviews as well as have time for all the non-CS things in life. I have seen people take on a similar courseload (I know I can't lmao) but it comes back down to being aware of what you are able to handle :))

I wouldn't necessarily say that CS 188 is unnecessary - I haven't taken it, but from what I've heard it's really useful to take before 189, especially since you're interested in studying AI.  I'd also recommend that you take EECS 126 and 127 before 189 rather than concurrently.  I'd also recommend you take CS 169 (software engineering) at some point, because the skills you learn from it, such as building large programming projects and programming in a group with other people, are applicable to other classes as well as real-world industry positions.  

-----

I have seen people take on a similar courseload (I know I can't lmao) but it comes back down to being aware of what you are able to handle :))

I wouldn't necessarily say that CS 188 is unnecessary - I haven't taken it, but from what I've heard it's really useful to take before 189, especially since you're interested in studying AI.  I'd also recommend that you take EECS 126 and 127 before 189 rather than concurrently.  I'd also recommend you take CS 169 (software engineering) at some point, because the skills you learn from it, such as building large programming projects and programming in a group with other people, are applicable to other classes as well as real-world industry positions.

children.subject: I have heard CS 162 and CS 161 to be good classes as well.

Data100 is much more useful if you take it before 189. It introduces many of the concepts covered in 189 - such as train/test splits, cross validation, regression (linear and logistics), classification, PCA - but in a much lighter manner, so that when you see the topic in 189 you have the basics down and can focus more on the nuance. 

100 after 189 is an afterthought. 

It's also one of the lighter upperdiv courses (since its designed to be like the first upper div you take) (at least when I took it fa18 it might have changed a lot since then) so it would be a good complement to harder classes in one semester
This is meant to be more of an outline but thanks I'll take it into consideration.

You're not gonna predict the future 4 years ahead. So definitely plan for multiple alternate schedules/orders and combinations in which you take your courses. This is to allow for course not being offered that semester, not getting off the wait list, time conflicts, etc.

I think I mean CS 280. I think I'll try to change my schedule so that there are mostly only two techs unless I think one of the techs is pretty easy. Honestly, I can't decide whether I want to do industry AI/ML. I want to do industry AI/ML work but I'm worried that in a few years the AI wave will stop, so that's why I also want to be prepared for industry regular SWE work. Ontop of that I really don't know what I want to go into yet (I just know industry) but I just want to know what courses I want to take. I'm not sure what I should do.

I am wart of your multiple semesters of 3 techs. IMO upper divs are tougher than lower divs, and if you are already feeling a bit of pressure, and you are very involved, you likely will be more involved as you progress in your 4 years due to taking on more leadership roles and putting more time into projects. Which is awesome! But that could be hard to balance with 3 techs, especially if 1 or 2, even 3 are hard. 

Also keep in mind classes aren't offered every semester. 

What is 194 computer vision? Do you mean 280 computer vision? Or 194-26, computational photography? (A class that has pretty much 0 AI in it)

Also whats your goal? Is it to do industry AI/ML work? Or industry regular software engineering work?

126/127 are super brutal from what I’ve heard. 61C is also quite a bit of work. From what I’ve been told, CS 170, EE 120, EE 126, EE 127, and CS 189 is enough preparation to leap you into grad level courses for AI/ML.
I didn't know they were difficult. I'll just move classes around then and probably take out some of the AI classes.
127 126 and 61c and you’re an “average” cs student?
This is moreso to help me get familiar with the courses offered. I took out 126 and 127 and the specific AI topic classes. Thanks for the advice!

I remembered after my first semester, I sat down and tried to properly plan out all the courses I wanted to take here at Berkeley and which semester I will take them. I don't know where that list went, but I will say I did really bad in following it. There's several reasons, i.e. courses aren't always offered consistently like you expect; some classes are just unlikely to get into unless you phase one; or more importantly, you might find other courses or newly offered courses more interesting. When I was a freshmen, CS182 wasn't a class, the Data Science major wasn't even an option, and there are a lot more new interesting special topics courses. The moral of the story, don't worry too much about designing a schedule. Do what seems right at the time and then take the classes that fit what you want; you might find yourself a better CS student than you expected and can handle harder course loads than that, or you might find a new extracurricular a certain semester and have less time available than originally planned. 

As more practical advice, I question the wisdom of dedicating an entire semester to solidifying mathematical foundations for AI; I took 189 with Sahai a few years ago without having taken 126 or 127, and while they may have been helpful I don't see them as essential as other people have been proclaiming. There's even less of a reason for taking 126 or 127 if you want to do SWE work in industry (although one other industry may require topics like that). In addition, don't lock yourself into taking specific AI/ML topics classes right now like computer vision or NLP; after you take 188 or 189 you may realize those topics aren't as interesting to you anymore (I know once I was really into computer vision and RL, but now I found a different area thats much more interesting to me). 

If you are really committing to this schedule, I'd recommend mixing software courses with theory courses, since it gives some nice mixup per semester. All the theory courses are homework due every week and then having multiple classes consistently requiring that is usually not good for your sanity; replacing one of them with a software course which has a project every few weeks and pretty light the others is helpful for balancing workload.

history.content:
I don't exactly know what I want to go into right now, but I'm leaning towards AI because it seems interesting. I'm definitely not going to grad school so I want my classes to be more focused on industry. This is my tentative four year plan. Keep in mind that I'm a very average CS student (A- in CS61A) and that I will also be busy with clubs and side projects so I will not be putting all my attention into my classes. Is the schedule doable for someone like me? Advice and critiques to make it optimal?
